content.description: Follow the featured, left-facing corner up past several ledges to an anchor. This is an enjoyable easy lead with good protection.
content.protection: Light rack, mostly medium cams. The crack is wide at the start, but large gear is not really needed.
content.location: There is a large open area near the lower (left) end of Guide's Wall. Its upper end is marked by a large, left-facing corner. That is the route.

content.description: Step up a short outside corner (crux, easily avoided by stepping in from the right) to a short left-facing corner below an overhang. Follow the left of two parallel cracks up to the grassy ledge and an anchor (shared with Scarecrow, the right crack).
content.location: This is the first clean route on the left end of Guide's Wall.  It starts at a short outside corner just left of two trees.

content.description: Follow the right-leaning crack, then step right to an anchor (shared with Firecracker). Awkward, reachy, and hard to protect well. The obvious flake lodged in the crack wiggles but doesn't seem to want to come out.
content.protection: Light rack with small to medium cams
content.location: Just right of the oak trees at the lower (left) end of Guide's Wall.

content.description: Follow the crack to the grassy ledge and an anchor (shared with Tin Man, the left crack). An easy, well-protected lead.
content.location: There are two short parallel cracks at the lower (left) end of Guide's Wall; this is the right crack. Start between two oak trees growing very near the cliff.

content.description: Pull up through the overhanging start on good holds. At the second bolt, undercling and jam up and right, following the obvious flake, to an anchor.
content.location: The start is shared with Cowboy Bebop, which moves left at the second bolt. It is located about 30' uphill (right) from the small right-facing corner of Madam Butterfly, at a small oak tree below a section of overhanging, very featured rock.

content.description: Move up the short right-leaning crack, then step left onto the face of the buttress and follow a wandering line of least resistance up to a very puzzling steep exit on the left. The anchor is a few feet up and right on a slab. "A wretched hive of scum and villainy," according to Obi-Wan Kenobi, but the quality of the climbing is much better than the appearance would suggest.
content.protection: Light rack to 3". The gear placements are tricky, but solid -- mostly in pockets or horizontals that are hard to see from below.
content.location: This route climbs the front of the dirty-looking buttress just uphill from the large, left-facing corner of Treasure Island. Start a few feet uphill from a large oak tree, near a short right-leaning crack system.

content.description: Start up a thin vertical crack system (optional gear placements), then climb straight up through an overhanging bulge on big holds. Continue up a slab (more optional gear placements) to an anchor set in the overhang at the top of the cliff. Probably the best route on the Guide's Wall.
content.location: About 50' uphill and right from the large Treasure Island corner, just right of a dirty right-leaning crack system, and directly below a large pine tree at the top of the cliff.

content.description: Climb the shallow right-facing corner, then pull over onto the face on the left above an overhang and continue to the anchor (shared with Common Ground). A committing lead.
content.protection: Light rack to 1", emphasizing small cams and Tricams. It's challenging to get good gear on this one.
content.location: A small right-facing corner, located about 15' uphill (right) from the large oak tree that marks the start of Common Ground.

content.description:
This is a very good route, similar to Million Muppet March but on mostly trad gear. It was named in memory of the late Jeff Kuller, longtime director of parks and recreation for the Town of Camden.  

  Follow a short crack system up through overhanging rock past a horizontal, then continue straight up the slab above, passing a bolt, to an anchor.
content.protection: One bolt, light rack to 2".  The gear is good, but inobvious, and strenuous to place as well. Watch out for large loose flakes to the left and right of the bolt, which avoids the need to protect behind those features.
content.location: Start below a section of overhanging rock, about 30' uphill (right) from the small oak tree of Cowboy Bebop, and just downhill (left) of a very large, double-trunked oak tree.

content.description: Pull up into the steep left-facing corner and layback to a small overhang, then step right and reach a pocket on the right face. Climb up past a wide horizontal onto an awkward ramp below a large overhang. Pull through the big overhang to an anchor.
content.protection: Two bolts, light rack to 1", plus one optional 4-5" cam; long sling for gear under the big overhang
content.location: Near the upper (right) end of Guide's Wall is a break with an easy left-leaning vegetated ramp. This route starts a few feet uphill (right) from the ramp, at a distinctive left-facing corner behind a very large double-trunked yellow birch tree.

content.description: Straight up the crack system to an anchor.
content.protection: Light rack with stoppers and medium cams
content.location: There is a large open area near the lower (left) end of Guide's Wall. Firecracker climbs a short vertical crack system in the center of this opening, just downhill from a very large oak tree.

content.description: Starting on the right, pull up onto the slab and mantel onto a ledge. Climb up past the horizontal onto a steep headwall, and follow good holds straight up to the anchor.
content.protection: Three bolts, # 1 Camalot or equivalent for the horizontal. Getting gear in the horizontal is important, so it's really not a sport route.
content.location: About 20' right (uphill) from the yellow birch tree and obvious left-facing corner of Jerry's Corner. This climb is the last clean face on the upper (right) end of Guide's Wall.

content.description: Pull up through the steep starting section on good rock. At the second bolt, step left onto a sloping ledge, another bolt, and a short vertical crack. The smooth headwall above, passing a horizontal crack, is the crux; mantel onto a nice ledge with an anchor.
content.protection: Three bolts, optional small cam in the horizontal near the top.
content.location: About 30' uphill (right) from the small right-facing corner of Madam Butterfly, at a small oak tree below a section of overhanging, featured rock. The start of this route is shared with The Real Folk Blues, which moves right after the second bolt.

content.description: Step up onto very featured horizontal ledges, then climb more or less straight up the steep wall on good holds. At the top, step right to the anchor (shared with Madam Butterfly).
content.protection: Two bolts, plus a light rack to 2"
content.location: This route starts a few feet uphill (right) from Million Muppet March, just below a large oak tree growing next to the cliff.

content.description: Climb up a short slab to a small ledge (same start as Alpine Spring). Follow the steep crack on the left through the overhang above, then step right past a small tree to an anchor shared with Alpine Spring.
content.location: Just uphill (right) from a very large double-trunked oak tree, and about 15' right of The Kuller. Same start as Alpine Spring.

content.description: Climb a short slab to a ledge (same start as Beautiful Garbage). Continue straight up the face, finishing up the steep right-facing corner with an overhang at the top to an anchor (shared with Beautiful Garbage).
content.location: Just uphill (right) of a very large double-trunked oak tree growing next to the cliff, about 15' right of The Kuller. (Same start as Beautiful Garbage.)

content.description: Guide's Wall has short (30-60'), mostly moderate routes on sometimes fragile schist. It is southeast facing and shaded by trees, so it's often best in the fall after the leaves are down. It dries slowly. Because it is not yet included in the guidebook, it gets little traffic. All routes have bolted belay/rappel anchors.
